ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the Middle East and about anthropological research and methods of writing.
We learned about different topics like medicine and pop culture in the middle east. The class focused on bringing forth different perspectives and facilitating intellectual discussion.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths are that the reading are interesting, the professor is very helpful and facilitates a stimulating discussion, the discussion-heavy class makes it easy to learn from other students, and the assignments leading up to the final paper help you be on the right track.
The reading are sometimes too long which makes it overwhelming to complete all of them.

The readings were very well chosen and structured. I really enjoyed how the class involved structured lessons and the opportunity to an open discussion. No weaknesses, it was a very enjoyable and educational class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if they have little knowledge about the Middle East as it is a way to learn a lot of new things. Also, I would recommend it whether you have a background in anthropology or not as it does not require any specific technical knowledge.
Yes, its different from other middle east courses because it doesnt take a US centric approach. It was a really great mix of anthropology and history.

extras.title: GLBL 322 01/MMES 310 01 - Society and Politics of ME
